html: Confronted with the reality of Jehovah’s presence, Isaiah feels a sense of unworthiness. As often occurs when a person sees God with his physical eyes, he is physically impaired—in this case “struck dumb” (nidmeti). Believing he is smitten with a covenant curse, Isaiah is afraid not only for himself but for his people—as we observe in the common imagery of “unclean lips” or “unclean speech” (teme’ sepatayim)—leaving him with a desire to help his people. The title of “King” reflects Jehovah’s kingship over all the earth and its inhabitants ( Isaiah 24:21-23; 33:17, 22; 37:16; 43:15; 44:6; 52:7).
